question: The opening episode of the twenty-first run of a long-running adult animated satire set in a fictional Colorado mountain town, which dealt with themes of home renovation and automated job displacement, was which overall instalment of the series?
llm_answer: I cannot verify the opening episode of the twenty-first run of a long-running adult animated satire set in a fictional Colorado mountain town.

context.text: " You Kent Always Say What You Want " is the twenty-second and final episode of the eighteenth season of the American animated television series The Simpsons . It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on May 20, 2007, as part of the one-hour season finale , alongside the episode " 24 Minutes ". It was the milestone 400th episode of The Simpsons and was written by Tim Long and directed by Matthew Nastuk . In this episode, Kent Brockman is fired for swearing on air and moves in to the Simpson home where he and Lisa investigate the Republican Party. The episode guest starred Ludacris as himself and Maurice LaMarche as the Fox announcer. It received positive reviews. It was the last episode to air prior to The Simpsons Movie , which was released two months later on July 27, 2007. Special opening In celebration of the 20th anniversary of the show (when counting the shorts), the entire opening sequence is replaced with a black screen that reads, "20 Years Ago..." followed by a showing of The Tracey Ullman Show Simpsons short "Family Portrait", which involves Homer failing the shot on multiple occasions. Plot Driving home after a trip to the dentist , Homer takes the Simpson family to an ice cream parlor , where he buys the store's millionth ice cream cone. This results in Homer appearing on Kent Brockman 's TV news talk show Smartline on Channel 6 since both have the same owner. Kent is disgusted that he is forced to do a fluff piece instead of an in-depth, intellectually stimulating discussion of the conflict in the Middle East . During the interview, Homer accidentally knocks Kent's cup of coffee into his lap, making him swear in pain. After the commercial break, Kent apologizes, but is relieved to find that, as the Internet has supplanted television as a source of news information, no one saw his on-air faux pas. However, Ned Flanders reviews the incident and gets people of alike minds to report it to the Federal Communications Commission . The next day, during the newscast, Kent finds out that he is under scrutiny for his indiscretion and that the station has been fined $10 million. He is demoted to weekend weatherman with his rival, Arnie Pye , as the new anchorman. Later, Lindsey Naegle speaks to Kent, assuring him that his job is safe, but fires him on the pretence that he has put cocaine in his coffee cup, ignoring his insistence that it is actually Splenda . Marge invites a suicidal Kent to sleep over at the Simpson house. While watching TV the next day, Lisa wonders why the cable channel Fox News can be so conservative while the Fox Network broadcasts sexualized content. Kent replies that Fox deliberately airs programs with morally reprehensible content so that they will be fined by the FCC, with the fines being funneled to the Republican Party . According to Brockman, everyone in

" At Long Last Leave " is the fourteenth episode of the twenty-third season of the American animated television series The Simpsons , and the 500th episode overall of the series. In this episode, the Simpsons discover that the inhabitants of Springfield have grown tired of them and have secretly decided to throw them out of the city. After being evicted from Springfield, the family members end up in a rugged place without rules and regulations called the Outlands. There, they briefly come across their neighbor Julian Assange , who created WikiLeaks . Assange guest-starred in the episode as himself and recorded his lines over the phone while under house arrest in Britain, while waiting for the results of Assange v Swedish Prosecution Authority . Michael Price wrote the episode without the intention of it becoming the 500th episode and felt honored when it was selected for the milestone. Television critics have given the episode generally positive reviews, particularly praising it for a montage of the series' couch gags that was included in the opening sequence . The storyline of "At Long Last Leave" has, however, received criticism for being similar to the main story structure previously done in The Simpsons Movie . During its original airing on the Fox network in the United States on February 19, 2012, the episode was watched by about 5.77 million people and received a 2.6 Nielsen rating in the demographic for adults aged 18–49 . Before this broadcast, Fox promoted the 500th episode milestone by arranging an attempt to break the Guinness World Record for longest continuous television viewing. A hundred fans of The Simpsons were invited to watch a marathon of the series' episodes, starting on February 8, 2012. The record was broken 86 hours and 37 minutes later on February 12, 2012, with only two fans left watching the marathon. Plot The Simpson family is advised of a citywide nuclear safety drill and all the inhabitants of Springfield are told to stay in their basements for three hours. The family members quickly become bored in the basement and decide to leave the house and go see the empty city. As they walk through Springfield, they see an unusual number of cars parked by the City Hall. The Simpsons go in and discover that everyone in town has gathered for a secret town meeting and have voted unanimously to kick them out of Springfield forever. Mayor Quimby reveals that the city has gone bankrupt due to the constant cleaning up of the family's shenanigans over the years, ranging from Homer 's drunken antics, Bart 's various pranks, and Lisa 's environmental concerns. Marge delivers a heart-felt plea to the residents to let the Simpsons live in the one place they call home, but they refuse, with Quimby declaring her the "worst Simpson" for always trying to see the family in a positive light. Ned attempts to defend the Simpsons by claiming no one should be quick to judge without being judged themselves. Quimby, having anticipated this, decides

1944, and 1945 football seasons. Tom Kaulukukui era (1946–1950) 1946 – Hawaiʻi resumes football play after a four-year hiatus as a member of the NCAA . Hawaiʻi enters as a College Division Independent. The Rainbows continue to play local teams on occasion but the bulk of their schedules are made up of collegiate teams. Hank Vasconcellos era (1952–1960) 1955 – A year after suffering a 50–0 blowout loss to Nebraska in Honolulu, the Rainbows go up to Lincoln the following season and upset the Huskers 6–0. The win is considered one of the school's all-time biggest upsets. 1961 – The UH Board of Athletic Control votes to abolish the football program due to a lack of finances. The program would return to intercollegiate competition the following year behind the urgings of new athletics director Young Suk Ko . Jim Asato era (1962–1964) Shaughnessy-Sarboe-King era (1965–1967) 1965 – Larry Price performed in his third Hula Bowl as a College All-Star after a stint in the U.S. Army where he performed twice for the Hawai'i All-Stars. Legendary coach Clark Shaughnessy takes over for one season but the Rainbows flounder through a 1–8–1 season. 1966 – Phil Sarboe, after 15 seasons as head coach at Humboldt State, guides the team to a 4–6 record playing its first all-collegiate schedule. He resigns for "personal reasons" after the season. 1967 – Don King, an assistant under Sarboe, becomes head coach and the much-improved Rainbows post a 6–4 record. Significantly, large crowds (18,000 to 20,000) flock to Honolulu Stadium to watch the Rainbows for the first time in many years, setting the stage for a major gridiron revival in future years. Dave Holmes era (1968–1973) 1968 – Head coach Dave Holmes begins what would be the most successful coaching tenure at Hawaiʻi. From 1968–1974, UH won 67 percent of its games and never suffered a losing season. Holmes still ranks as the all-time leader at Hawaiʻi in winning percentage (.718). Drafted by the Dallas Cowboys in the 16th round, Larry Cole becomes the first UH Warrior to be drafted by an NFL team. Cole was a one-year transfer from the United States Air Force Academy and later graduated from the University of Houston . 1971 – Larry Cole becomes the first former Warrior to represent UH in world championship competition in Super Bowl V for the Dallas Cowboys . 1972 – Larry Cole becomes the first former Warrior to start for a world champion football team with

The twenty-third season of the American animated sitcom The Simpsons aired on Fox between September 25, 2011, and May 20, 2012. The season was produced by Gracie Films and 20th Century Fox Television . The showrunner for the season was Al Jean , with three episodes ran with Matt Selman , one of those he also wrote himself. The show's 500th episode, " At Long Last Leave ," aired February 19, 2012. On October 7, 2011, the series was renewed for a twenty-fourth and twenty-fifth season . The season was nominated for two Primetime Emmy Awards , for three Writers Guild of America Awards , winning one, and for four Annie Awards , winning one. Voice cast & characters Main cast Dan Castellaneta as Homer Simpson , Charlie , Barney Gumble , Grampa Simpson , Arnie Pye , Groundskeeper Willie , Krusty the Clown , Kodos , Itchy , Santa's Little Helper , Benjamin , Sideshow Mel , Mayor Quimby , Gil Gunderson , Hans Moleman , Rich Texan , Mr. Teeny , Blue-Haired Lawyer , Squeaky-Voiced Teen , Snowball II and various others Julie Kavner as Marge Simpson , Patty Bouvier and Selma Bouvier Nancy Cartwright as Bart Simpson , Kearney Zzyzwicz , Nelson Muntz , Ralph Wiggum , Todd Flanders , Database and various others Yeardley Smith as Lisa Simpson Hank Azaria as Comic Book Guy , Carl Carlson , Moe Szyslak , Snake , Superintendent Chalmers , The Grumple , Sea Captain , State Comptroller Atkins , Chief Wiggum , Lou , Wiseguy , Cletus Spuckler , Old Jewish Man , Dr. Nick Riviera , Professor Frink , Doug , Kirk Van Houten , Ron Rabinowitz , Apu Nahasapeemapetilon , Nash Castor , Duffman , Julio , Luigi Risotto , Disco Stu , Drederick Tatum , Chazz Busby and various others Harry Shearer as Lenny Leonard , Kent Brockman , Ned Flanders , Principal Skinner , Otto Mann , Dewey Largo , Mr. Burns , God , Kang , Scratchy , Jasper Beardly , Gary , Waylon Smithers , Judge Synder , Reverend Lovejoy , Dr. Hibbert , Nedward Flanders, Sr. and various others Supporting cast Chris Edgerly as additional characters Pamela Hayden as Milhouse Van Houten , Jimbo Jones , Rod Flanders , Janey Powell , Capri Flanders and various others Tress MacNeille as Dolph Shapiro , Lunchlady Dora , Mrs. Muntz , Agnes Skinner , Crazy Cat Lady , Brandine Spuckler , Manjula Nahasapeemapetilon , Allison Taylor , Shauna Chalmers , Cookie Kwan ,

The 2012 Hawaii Warriors football team represented the University of Hawaii at Manoa in the 2012 NCAA Division I FBS football season . They were led by first-year head coach Norm Chow and played their home games at Aloha Stadium . They were first year members of the Mountain West Conference . They finished the season 3–9, 1–7 in Mountain West play to finish in a tie for ninth place. New head coach In December 2011, the university hired Norm Chow , a native Hawaiian who had most recently served as the offensive coordinator at Utah , as its head coach to replace the retiring Greg McMackin . With Chow's hiring, the Warriors abandoned the run and shoot offense that McMackin's predecessor June Jones installed and instead ran a pro-style offense . Codename: Kids Next Door is an American animated spy fiction television series created by Mr. Warburton for Cartoon Network . It was produced by Curious Pictures with assistance from Cartoon Network Studios . The series follows the adventures of a diverse group of five children who operate from a high-tech treehouse , fighting against adult and teenage tyranny with advanced 2×4 technology. Using their code names (Numbuhs 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5), they are Sector V, part of a global organization called the Kids Next Door. The series' pilot premiered on Cartoon Network in mid-2001 as part of The Big Pick II , a special broadcast event showcasing 11 pilots for different series. The winner of a viewers' poll by Cartoon Network would decide which pilot would be greenlit to be a full series. After winning the poll, the series premiered on December 6, 2002, and concluded on January 21, 2008, after six seasons and 81 episodes. Two television films were broadcast: Operation: Z.E.R.O. , which aired in 2006, and Operation: I.N.T.E.R.V.I.E.W.S. , which aired as the series finale in 2008. A special half-hour crossover episode with fellow Cartoon Network series, The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy , aired in 2007. Spin-off media include two video games, Operation S.O.D.A. and Operation V.I.D.E.O.G.A.M.E. , as well as a trading card game, comic books, and DVD releases. Codename: Kids Next Door has also appeared in DVD anthologies and compilation video games from Cartoon Network. Overview From left to right: Numbuh 2, Numbuh 4, Numbuh 3, Numbuh 1, and Numbuh 5. Synopsis The series revolves around a diverse group of five 10-year-old children (later retconned to be varying ages), using codenames Numbuhs 1 through 5, who are the main home operatives of what is known as Sector V, which is part of a worldwide global espionage-style organization called the Kids Next Door. Their mission is to fight crimes against children (such as homework , flossing , doctor , baths, bedtime, teeth brushing, babysitters , sharing, doing chores, etc.), many of which are willingly committed by "evil" adults , senior citizens , teenagers , and occasionally other children. Numbuh 1 is a level-headed, no-nonsense British boy named Nigel Uno, leader of Sector V. Numbuh 2 is an overweight, nerdy American boy named Hogarth "Hoagie" Pennywhistle Gilligan, Jr. Numbuh 3 is a friendly, happy-go-lucky Japanese girl named Kuki Sanban. Numbuh 4 is a short-tempered, irrational Australian boy named Wallabee

( UC Health ) was created in 1991 to allow the Regents to reorganize the University of Colorado Hospital . International collaboration The university is an active member of the University of the Arctic . UArctic is an international cooperative network based in the Circumpolar Arctic region, consisting of more than 200 universities, colleges, and other organizations with an interest in promoting education and research in the Arctic region . The Untouchables of Elliot Mouse is a 1996–1997 26-episode half-hour television animated cartoon series loosely inspired by the real life Eliot Ness and his group of agents colloquially known as the Untouchables with their investigation into the real life gangster Al Capone . As with past adaptations this one does take some liberties with history. The series also parodies the violent atmosphere of Chicago during the Dry Law , as well as the old American films, their heroes and villains. The main characters in this series are four friendly mice: Elliot "Mouse", Gordon, Mr. Wilson, and Jack the Irishman, although there are also some cats and dogs. Plot The citizens of "Cheesecago" are defenceless against "Al Catone's" mobsters until a few brave federal agents from the "Federal Mousehole of Investigation" headed by "Elliot Mouse" dare to take on the gangsters. In spite of their rivalry and continuous fights, they control gambling, shows, races and every business in town. They charge poor people and terrified traders with high taxes; they rob, and kidnap, but their biggest racket is in confiscating cheese and then deal with it illegally so that it fetches very high prices, often causing Cheesecago citizens to get ripped off. Episode Cheesecago: City Without Law Moony's Big Haul The First Raids The Cheese Trail Doubles or Nothing The Informer A Day at the Races Ma Wilson The Perfect Holdup The Greater the Fall The Starlette The Cheesecago Express Escape from Catatraz The Trap The Code of Silence Like Dog and Cat The Public Enemy A Present from Santa Mouse The Loot goes Flying The School of Crime Their Days are Numbered The Stolen Armstrong Gems and Diamonds While the City Sleeps The Kidnapping A Matter of Taxes Special Happy 20th Anniversary to The Untouchables of Elliot Mouse! The Untouchables vs Al Catone (full film) Characters Elliot Mouse Gordon Mr. Wilson Jack the Irishman Deborah Pierre The Cheese Paree Band Louis (Trumpet), Artie (Drums), Jim (Double Bass) and Thelonious (Piano) Moony Robin Junior Tino Beradi Al Catone Rat Nitti Anselmi Scalise Dog Moran Kevin Sharp Nose Johnny Police Chief Stunned Mayor Big Bit Thompson Walter Sum Release The first 9 episodes were released on DVD in the UK. Sometime in late 2013 to early 2014, the complete series of The Untouchables of Elliot Mouse was released on DVD in the UK. References External links The Untouchables of Elliot Mouse at IMDb BRB Internacional See also Dog City Who Framed Roger Rabbit The Untouchables (film) The Untouchables (book)

from the bottom 60%. Extracurriculars The small campus of 2,000 students boasts more than one hundred clubs and student groups, ranging from professional groups, interests clubs, and social groups. Among them are intramural sports groups, which have a strong presence on campus. There are intramural teams, ranging from broomball to ultimate frisbee. Student newspaper The Catalyst is a weekly newspaper published by students of Colorado College on Friday mornings throughout of the school year. It is the official and only student paper at the school and has a print circulation of roughly 1,500 circulated on the college's campus and in downtown Colorado Springs. The Catalyst consists of five sections: News, Sports, Active Life, Life, and Opinion. It has been in print since the 1890s, and has undergone dozens of transformations over the years. The newspaper was originally called The Tiger .  Housing Most students live on or directly adjacent to the college campus. Up until their junior year, students are required to live on campus in one of the residence halls or small houses, while apartments and student-owned cottages are available to upperclassmen. Campus Cutler Hall, located at 912 North Cascade Avenue, on the Colorado College campus, in Colorado Springs, Colorado. The property is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Many of the earliest campus buildings, including Bemis , Cossitt , Cutler , McGregor , Montgomery , Palmer , and Ticknor Halls, are on the National Register of Historic Places , along with Shove Memorial Chapel and the William I. Spencer Center . Arthur House or Edgeplain , once home to the son of President Chester A. Arthur , is also on the National Register. Since the mid-1950s, newer facilities include three large residence halls, Worner Campus Center, Olin Hall of Science and the Barnes Science Center, Honnen Ice Rink, Boettcher Health Center, Schlessman Pool, Armstrong Hall of Humanities, and the El Pomar Sports Center. The face of campus changed again at the beginning of the 21st century with construction of the Western Ridge Housing Complex, which offers apartment-style living for upper-division students and completion of the Russell T. Tutt Science Center. The east campus has been expanded, and is now home to the Greek Quad and several small residence halls known as "theme houses".  Some of the more recent notable buildings include Tutt Library, designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and later expanded and renovated by Pfeiffer Partners to be the largest carbon-neutral academic library in the United States, Packard Hall of Music and Art, designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes , and the Edith Kinney Gaylord Cornerstone Arts Center, which was designed by Antoine Predock with input from faculty and students.  Edith Kinney Gaylord Cornerstone Arts Center at Colorado College Edith Kinney Gaylord Cornerstone Arts Center Colorado College's

than I will be in the one where that inevitably stops." Tim Goodman of The Hollywood Reporter wrote: "I got a few laughs and that's all I ever look for in The Simpsons these days. I just like knowing it's still there. ... It doesn't have the spring in the legs quite like it used to. It's not going to dazzle at the same spectacular rate. But even after 500 episodes, it still has a little something left." Goodman described the couch gag as "lovely". Matt Roush of TV Guide wrote favorably about "At Long Last Leave", describing it as a "keeper" and highlighting the "dazzling opening sequence". He concluded that The Simpsons "once again delivers the goods, proving itself to be a classic for our age and for the ages." Childs was less positive, writing that the episode is "nothing special" as "all of the elements seem drawn from earlier stories" and "only a few of the jokes rise to the lowered bar of latter-day Simpsons humor." He added, however, that "nothing in the episode goes outrageously wrong, either. There is little Family Guy -style stupidity and randomness, the satire is gently pointed inward, and the guest star, while splashy for his controversiality, does not hijack the plot—instead appearing for a single joke before vanishing." Time critic James Poniewozik commented that "At Long Last Leave" was an "all right" episode, noting that certain gags felt "forced by the writers' room". He added however that "a few moments made me bark out loud and realize why I loved the show in the first place." References External links Wikiquote has quotations related to "At Long Last Leave" . The Simpsons portal "At Long Last Leave" at TheSimpsons.com "At Long Last Leave" at IMDb

communities.summary:
**Title**: The Untouchables of Elliot Mouse

**Summary**:  
The Untouchables of Elliot Mouse is a 1996–1997 animated series that parodies 1920s Chicago and the real-life Untouchables' battle against Al Capone, reimagined with anthropomorphic mice and cats. Set in "Cheesecago," the show follows federal agents led by Elliot Mouse as they combat Al Catone’s cheese-smuggling mob. The 26-episode series blends gangster-film tropes, Prohibition-era satire, and slapstick adventure, featuring characters like Jack the Irishman and Rat Nitti. It was released on DVD in the UK, including a full-length film compilation.

**Keywords**: animated parody, Prohibition satire, Elliot Mouse, Al Catone, Cheesecago

**Title**: Harvey Beaks Series Overview

**Summary**: Harvey Beaks is a Nickelodeon animated series that premiered in March 2015, following the adventures of a friendly bird named Harvey and his impish twin friends Fee and Foo in the enchanted Littlebark Grove. After an initial 52-episode run across two seasons, the show was shifted to the Nicktoons channel in 2017. Created by C. H. Greenblatt, the program blends gentle humor with woodland fantasy as the trio explores their magical forest home.

**Keywords**: Harvey Beaks, Nickelodeon, C. H. Greenblatt, Littlebark Grove, Nicktoons

**Title**: Colorado College Campus Life & Academics

**Summary**: Colorado College is a selective private liberal-arts school of ~2,000 students where undergrads follow a distinctive one-course-at-a-time “block plan.” Most first-years through juniors live on or next to the 90-acre campus, which blends National-Register historic halls with award-winning newer facilities such as the carbon-neutral Tutt Library and the Predock-designed Cornerstone Arts Center. Outside the classroom, students choose from 100+ clubs, active intramural sports, and the long-running student newspaper *The Catalyst*. Popular majors include Economics, Political Science, and Ecology, and the college is ranked among the nation’s most innovative liberal-arts institutions.

**Keywords**: Colorado College, block plan, campus housing, Tutt Library, student clubs

**Title**: 2012 Hawaii Warriors Football Season

**Summary**:  
The 2012 Hawaii Warriors football team, under first-year head coach Norm Chow, transitioned into the Mountain West Conference and ended the season with a 3–9 overall record and 1–7 in conference play, tying for ninth place. Chow, a native Hawaiian and former Utah offensive coordinator, replaced the retiring Greg McMackin and shifted the team’s offensive strategy from the run-and-shoot to a pro-style system. Home games were held at Aloha Stadium, and the schedule included matchups against USC, BYU, Boise State, and other Mountain West opponents.

**Keywords**: Hawaii Warriors, Norm Chow, Mountain West Conference, 2012 season, Aloha Stadium

**Title**: Gomer Pyle Pop-Culture Legacy

**Summary**:  
The wholesome, drawling Marine private Gomer Pyle—originating in *The Andy Griffith Show* and spun off into *Gomer Pyle, U.S.M.C.*—has become a durable pop-culture touchstone. His signature exclamation “Surprise, surprise, surprise!” is repeatedly quoted or parodied across decades of film and television, from *Forrest Gump* and *Good Morning, Vietnam* to animated series like *The Simpsons* and *Pinky and the Brain*. These callbacks uniformly invoke Gomer’s naïve optimism and distinctive voice to evoke both nostalgia and gentle satire of military or small-town archetypes.

**Keywords**:  
Gomer Pyle, Surprise catchphrase, Pop-culture references, Military satire, Television nostalgia

**Title**: Simpsons Satire on Media & Politics  

**Summary**:  
The episode “You Kent Always Say What You Want” (S18E22, the 400th episode) satirizes media hypocrisy and political corruption: after Kent Brockman swears on-air, FCC fines cost him his job, leading Lisa to uncover a Fox/Republican Party scheme where FCC fines from raunchy Fox shows secretly fund GOP coffers. Despite Brockman’s on-line exposé, party bosses silence him with a lucrative re-hire, underscoring the show’s theme that contemporary media lacks courage or integrity. The episode layers pop-culture parodies—from Edward R. Murrow to Rolling Stones lyrics—while lampooning real-world events like the Janet Jackson “wardrobe malfunction” fallout and Don Imus’s firing.  

**Keywords**:  
The Simpsons, media satire, FCC fines, Fox News, Republican Party

**Title**: The Simpsons 500th Episode Reception  

**Summary**:  
“At Long Last Leave,” the 500th episode of The Simpsons, sees the family exiled from Springfield to the anarchic Outlands after the town tires of their antics. Critics praised the nostalgic couch-gag montage and guest Julian Assange’s brief cameo, yet faulted the recycled plot reminiscent of The Simpsons Movie. Reviews were mixed-to-positive: some hailed it as a “keeper” that still delivers laughs, while others felt it merely echoed earlier stories with only sporadic humor. The episode drew 5.77 million U.S. viewers and was promoted via a Guinness-record marathon.  

**Keywords**:  
500th episode, Springfield exile, couch-gag montage, Julian Assange cameo, critical reception

**Title**: Westport Adventure Park Transformation

**Summary**: Westport Adventure Park in Westport, Ireland, replaced the long-running Pirate Adventure Park, which closed in September 2023 after 50 years. The new €5 million facility opened in 2024, featuring attractions like a giant swing, zip lines, and a climbing zone. The original pirate-themed park, developed by the 11th Marquess of Sligo, celebrated local legend Grace O'Malley and included Ireland’s first flume ride, Pirates Plunge.

**Keywords**: Westport Adventure Park, Pirate Adventure Park, Westport House, Grace O'Malley, Ireland attractions

**Title**: The Celebrity Apprentice Seasons & Winners  

**Summary**:  
The Celebrity Apprentice is a reality-TV spin-off of The Apprentice in which famous contestants compete to raise money for charity. Hosted first by Donald Trump (seasons 7–14) and later by Arnold Schwarzenegger (season 15), the show follows the original Apprentice format but eliminates communal living and job stakes. Seasons 7–9 and 11–15 are branded as Celebrity Apprentice, with winners including Piers Morgan, Joan Rivers, Bret Michaels, John Rich, Arsenio Hall, Trace Adkins, Leeza Gibbons, and Matt Iseman. After Trump’s 2015 presidential bid, NBC severed ties with him and rebooted the series with Schwarzenegger, but low ratings led to its cancellation in 2017. International adaptations exist in Australia, Ireland, Norway, and the UK.  

**Keywords**: Celebrity Apprentice, Donald Trump, Arnold Schwarzenegger, reality TV, charity competition

**Title**: The Simpsons Season 23

**Summary**: The twenty-third season of *The Simpsons* aired from September 2011 to May 2012, marking the show’s 500th episode milestone. Al Jean remained primary showrunner, with Matt Selman co-showrunning several episodes, and the season featured guest stars like Gordon Ramsay, Neil Gaiman, and Joan Rivers. A viewer vote over the summer determined whether characters Ned Flanders and Edna Krabappel would continue their relationship, with results revealed in the premiere. The season earned multiple award nominations, including Emmys and Annies, and showcased the series’ enduring cultural relevance.

**Keywords**: The Simpsons, Season 23, 500th episode, Ned and Edna, viewer vote

**Title:** Codename: Kids Next Door Universe

**Summary:**  
Codename: Kids Next Door is an animated spy-fi series that follows Sector V, a team of five kids using 2×4 technology to battle adult and teen tyranny. The show features a global KND organization, shadowy internal factions like the Splinter Cell, and a rogues’ gallery led by Father—Nigel Uno’s uncle—who permanently brainwashed Sector Z into the Delightful Children. Key antagonists include traitorous operatives such as Chad Dickson and Cree Lincoln, while the overarching narrative explores themes of loyalty, aging out, and covert manipulation within the KND hierarchy.

**Keywords:** Kids Next Door, Sector V, Father, Splinter Cell, delightfulization

**Title**: Hawaii State Legislature Operations  

**Summary**:  
The Hawaii State Legislature is a bicameral, part-time body comprising a 25-member Senate and a 51-member House, both elected without term limits. It meets in regular 60-working-day sessions every odd year, with bills introduced in the first year carry-over to the second; unfinished bills die at the biennium’s end. Legislators must be Hawaii residents for over three years, of majority age, and qualified voters in their districts. The governor can veto bills, which can be overridden only by a two-thirds vote of both chambers; appropriation vetoes are absolute. Since 1969 the legislature has convened in the Hawaii State Capitol in Honolulu, except for a 1991-1996 closure for asbestos removal and renovation.

**Title**: Randy J. Goodwin Profile  

**Summary**:  
Randy J. Goodwin, born Ivan Jerome Goodwin on December 24, 1967, is an American actor recognized for roles such as Kennedy Winslow in *Fast Track* and Max Ellis in *Abby*, plus recurring parts on *Girlfriends* and *The Vampire Diaries*. Beyond acting, he served on the GBT Academy of the Arts Advisory Board as both actor and writer. In 2013 he prepared to make his feature directing debut with the Christian film *The Job*, which he co-wrote and will star in.  

**Keywords**: Randy J. Goodwin, actor, Fast Track, The Vampire Diaries, The Job

**Title**: The Simpsons 500th Episode Milestone

**Summary**:  
"At Long Last Leave," the 500th episode of *The Simpsons*, centers on the Simpson family being exiled from Springfield and finding acceptance in the lawless Outlands, only for the townspeople to follow them there. The episode, written by Michael Price, was intentionally crafted as a tribute to long-time fans and references the show’s history. It features guest appearances by Julian Assange and others, and was promoted with a record-breaking marathon. Critics praised its nostalgic couch gag and emotional resonance, despite familiar plot beats.

**Keywords**:  
The Simpsons, 500th episode, At Long Last Leave, Springfield exile, Julian Assange

**Title**: Emilie de Ravin's Acting Career

**Summary**: Emilie de Ravin gained prominence through her role as Belle on ABC’s fantasy drama Once Upon a Time, becoming a series regular after initially guest-starring. She first rose to wider attention on the hit series Lost, which drew massive audiences throughout its run. Her filmography spans indie and mainstream cinema, including the neo-noir Brick, the horror remake The Hills Have Eyes, the romantic drama Remember Me opposite Robert Pattinson, and the indie feature The Submarine Kid. She has also appeared in Public Enemies and The Perfect Game, and was once attached to the video-game adaptation Onimusha before its cancellation.

**Keywords**: Emilie de Ravin, Once Upon a Time, Lost, Remember Me, filmography

**Title**: Hawaii State Senate Structure  

**Summary**:  
The Hawaii State Senate is the 25-member upper chamber of the Hawaii State Legislature, meeting part-time in Honolulu’s State Capitol. Senators serve four-year terms without term limits, and since 1963 Democrats have held uninterrupted control, achieving a one-party 25-seat lock from 2016-2018. The body originated as the Kingdom’s House of Nobles in 1840, became the modern Senate under the 1894 Republic constitution, and elects internal officers including a President (currently Ron Kouchi) and support staff.  

**Keywords**: Hawaii Senate, Democratic supermajority, 25 districts, part-time legislature, Honolulu Capitol

**Title**: 2006 Hawaii Warriors Season

**Summary**:  
The 2006 Hawaii Warriors football team achieved an 11-win season, tying the school record and finishing second in the WAC behind undefeated Boise State. Quarterback Colt Brennan set NCAA single-season records with 58 touchdown passes and a 185.96 efficiency rating, earning sixth in Heisman voting and WAC Offensive Player of the Year honors. The Warriors capped their historic season with a 41–24 Hawaii Bowl victory over Arizona State, while head coach June Jones was named WAC Coach of the Year and nine players earned All-WAC first-team recognition.

**Keywords**:  
Colt Brennan, Hawaii Bowl, WAC, June Jones, 11-win season

**Title:** Hawaii Rainbow Warriors Football 2019–2023  

**Summary:**  
The 2019 season marked Hawaii’s most successful campaign in eight years, featuring a 10–5 record, a Mountain West division title, and a dramatic Hawaii Bowl win over BYU behind Cole McDonald’s 493-yard, 4-TD performance. Head coach Nick Rolovich earned Mountain West Coach of the Year honors before departing for Washington State, prompting the hiring of Todd Graham. Graham’s 2020 squad notched a third straight winning season and a New Mexico Bowl victory, but 2021 saw Aloha Stadium shuttered, forcing on-campus games and ending with Graham’s resignation amid player-mistreatment allegations. Timmy Chang, a former UH quarterback, took over in 2022; his first two seasons produced 3–10 and 5–8 records while the program coped with mass transfers and facility uncertainty. Throughout these years, Hawaii’s rivalries with Fresno State, Air Force, and Wyoming remained central, with trophies like the Golden Screwdriver, Kuter, and Paniolo at stake.

**Keywords:**  
Hawaii Rainbow Warriors, Nick Rolovich, Todd Graham, Timmy Chang, Mountain West Conference

**Title:** Hawaii Rainbow Warriors Football History  

**Summary:**  
The Hawaii Rainbow Warriors football program, representing the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, has evolved from its 1909 debut as the “Fighting Deans” through multiple conference affiliations and identity changes. Key milestones include the 1920s “Wonder Teams,” WWII hiatus, 1979 Western Athletic Conference entry, and 2012 Mountain West membership. The team gained national prominence under coaches Dick Tomey, Bob Wagner, and June Jones, highlighted by the 2007 undefeated regular season, Sugar Bowl berth, and NCAA records set by quarterback Colt Brennan.  

**Keywords:**  
Rainbow Warriors, June Jones era, Colt Brennan, WAC/Mountain West, 2007 undefeated season

**Title**: 2006 Hawaii Warriors Football Season

**Summary**:  
The 2006 Hawaii Warriors football team, led by record-setting quarterback Colt Brennan, achieved significant success both individually and as a team. Brennan earned numerous accolades, including WAC Offensive Player of the Year, Sammy Baugh Trophy, and multiple All-American honors. The team showcased a high-powered offense, with standout performances from players like Davone Bess and Nate Ilaoa. Despite narrow losses to ranked opponents like Alabama and Boise State, Hawaii secured key victories over UNLV, Eastern Illinois, Nevada, and Fresno State. Several players received All-WAC recognition, and multiple Warriors were selected in the 2007 NFL Draft.

**Keywords**:  
Colt Brennan, Hawaii Warriors, 2006 season, WAC awards, NFL draft

**Title**: Celebrity Apprentice 2011 Finale

**Summary**: John Rich edged out Marlee Matlin to win the 2011 Celebrity Apprentice after a final 7UP Retro campaign that included designing a can, filming a commercial, and hosting a gala. Although Matlin led early, Rich closed a $300k fundraising gap—ultimately raising $1.04m—while Matlin opted not to fundraise, a decision Trump cited as decisive. Both finalists received $50k from 7UP before the task, and the live finale featured post-task arguments, absent contestants (Dionne Warwick, Jose Canseco, Richard Hatch), and on-stage sparring between Star Jones and NeNe Leakes.

**Keywords**: Celebrity Apprentice, John Rich, Marlee Matlin, 7UP Retro, fundraising

**Title**: 2006 Hawaii Warriors Historic Season  

**Summary**:  
The 2006 Hawaii Warriors, led by quarterback Colt Brennan, produced one of the most prolific offensive seasons in college football history. Brennan shattered the NCAA single-season touchdown-pass record with 58 TDs and amassed 5,549 passing yards, joining an elite group of 5,000-yard/50-TD passers. Receiver Jason Rivers set bowl-game receiving marks while the offense topped national charts in total yards, passing, and scoring. The team rode a nine-game win streak, finished 11-3, matched the school victory record, and accepted an early Hawaii Bowl invitation where they capped the year by defeating Arizona State 41-24. Coach June Jones became Hawaii’s all-time winningest coach, and multiple Warriors earned weekly conference and national honors.  

**Keywords**: Colt Brennan, June Jones, NCAA records, Hawaii Bowl, 2006 season

**Title**: Alaska Legislature Structure & Process  

**Summary**:  
The Alaska State Legislature is the nation’s smallest bicameral body, with 40 representatives and 20 senators elected without term limits. Representatives serve two-year terms, while senators serve four-year terms, with half of the Senate elected every two years. Annual sessions are statutorily capped at 90 days, beginning in January, and may be extended by special sessions. Bills follow a standard path: introduction, committee referral, three readings, passage in the opposite chamber, and potential conference committee reconciliation before reaching the governor, who can sign or veto—though Alaska lacks a pocket-veto option. Unique to Alaska, bipartisan majority caucuses routinely form, incorporating minority-party “Bush Democrats.” Legislators’ short sessions allow outside employment, preserving a semi-volunteer character.  

**Keywords**:  
Alaska Legislature, bicameral structure, 90-day session, bipartisan caucus, legislative process

**Title**: Celebrity Apprentice Season 8 Finale

**Summary**:  
Season 8 of *The Celebrity Apprentice* culminated in a live finale where Joan Rivers was chosen over Annie Duke despite Annie raising more money and having a stronger overall track record. The final decision hinged on Joan winning three of five judged categories—Kodak branding, celebrity integration, and guest experience—while Annie only won two: money raised and charity integration. Joan, at 75, was praised for her resilience and stamina, while Annie was acknowledged for her strategic prowess and professionalism. The finale also featured notable absences and returns, and set records for fundraising, with Brande Roderick breaking Joan’s previous single-task record.

**Keywords**:  
Celebrity Apprentice, Joan Rivers, Annie Duke, finale, fundraising

**Title:** Hawaii Rainbow Warriors Football Alumni  

**Summary:**  
The University of Hawai‘i Rainbow Warriors football program has produced a large, accomplished network of players and coaches who have gone on to successful NFL, CFL, and collegiate careers. Notable alumni include multiple Super Bowl champions (Jesse Sapolu, Maa Tanuvasa, Adrian Klemm, Jason Elam, Marcus Kemp), Pro Bowlers, and high NFL draft picks (Ashley Lelie, Jahlani Tavai, Travis LaBoy). Many former players—such as Timmy Chang, Nick Rolovich, Ken Niumatalolo, and Brian Smith—have returned to coaching, with several leading Division I programs or serving as coordinators. The list also highlights specialists like record-setting kicker Jason Elam and Pro Bowl punter Rigoberto Sanchez, underscoring the program’s breadth of talent across positions.  

**Keywords:**  
Hawaii football alumni, NFL Super Bowl champions, Rainbow Warriors coaches, NFL draft picks

**Title**: Celebrity Apprentice Season 11 Highlights

**Summary**:  
These chunks chronicle key episodes from Season 11 of *The Celebrity Apprentice*, focusing on task outcomes, boardroom drama, and contestant dynamics. Notable moments include Dionne Warwick's self-sabotaging boardroom exit, Gary Busey's disorganized leadership leading to his firing, and the women's team (A.S.A.P.) outperforming the men in a charity art sale. Tensions repeatedly flare between Star Jones and NeNe Leakes over project management and credit, while Trump evaluates contestants based on fundraising ability, brand alignment, and team perception rather than task performance alone.

**Keywords**:  
Celebrity Apprentice, boardroom drama, Star Jones, NeNe Leakes, charity fundraising

**Title**: University of Colorado System Overview

**Summary**:  
The University of Colorado (CU) is a four-campus public university system anchored by the flagship CU Boulder, the fastest-growing UCCS, the research-intensive CU Denver, and the health-sciences-focused CU Anschutz Medical Campus. Together they enroll over 73,000 students, offer hundreds of degree programs, and conduct more than $420 million in annual research. Governance is by an elected nine-member Board of Regents, with Todd Saliman serving as system president. A former satellite campus, CU South Denver, closed in 2021, while UC Health and Arctic research collaborations extend the system’s reach beyond Colorado.

**Keywords**:  
CU campuses, Colorado public universities, CU Boulder flagship, CU Anschutz medical, UC Health
